question_details.query: How do long-term and temporary fishery closures compare in their effects on marine fish abundance?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence on temporary closures reported that a before-and-after, site comparison study found no increase in the spawning stock biomass of cod following a temporary fishery closure over nine years, compared to fished areas [2664]. Evidence on long-term closures reported mixed abundance outcomes: two site comparison studies found a higher abundance of only one of seven fish species and a lower abundance of monkfish in areas closed to groundfish fisheries for six to eight years compared to open areas; one replicated, before-and-after study found more young salmon and similar numbers of older salmon returning to rivers in the five years after a long-term coastal fishery closure; and another replicated, before-and-after study found lesser sandeel biomass and density peaked but showed no overall increase over three years after a long-term fishery closure [2655].
summary_statements: A before-and-after, site comparison study found no increase in the spawning stock biomass of cod following a temporary fishery closure over nine years, compared to fished areas.
Evidence on long-term closures reported mixed abundance outcomes.
Two site comparison studies found a higher abundance of only one of seven fish species in areas closed to groundfish fisheries for six to eight years compared to open areas.
Two site comparison studies found a lower abundance of monkfish in areas closed to groundfish fisheries for six to eight years compared to open areas.
One replicated, before-and-after study found more young salmon returning to rivers in the five years after a long-term coastal fishery closure.
One replicated, before-and-after study found similar numbers of older salmon returning to rivers in the five years after a long-term coastal fishery closure.
Another replicated, before-and-after study found lesser sandeel biomass and density peaked but showed no overall increase over three years after a long-term fishery closure.

question_details.query: What are the observed effects on fish abundance and diversity from prohibiting most or all fishing within Marine Protected Areas?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across 20 site-comparison studies, prohibiting all fishing in MPAs for 1–25+ years often corresponded with higher fish species richness in 14 studies, while six found similar richness and one systematic review found no difference; community composition differed from fished areas in seven studies (2682). Regarding abundance, 30 of 54 site-comparison studies and five of six reviews reported higher fish abundance/biomass in no-fishing MPAs, though eight studies found similar abundances and 16 found mixed effects varying by species, trophic level, size, duration, or habitat; one study reported long-term declines of some sharks where enforcement was poor (2682). In MPAs with zonation, no-fishing/no-entry zones had higher species numbers than partially fished zones and unprotected areas after 10–15 years (2674), and greater fish biomass/abundance than fished zones and outside areas after 3–27 years, though effects varied by fish group, size, reef region, and protection level (2674).
summary_statements: Prohibiting all fishing in Marine Protected Areas (MPAs) for 1 to over 25 years often corresponded with higher fish species richness in 14 site-comparison studies.
Six site-comparison studies found similar fish species richness between areas with and without fishing prohibitions.
One systematic review found no difference in fish species richness between areas with and without fishing prohibitions.
In seven studies, fish community composition in no-fishing areas differed from community composition in fished areas.

Eight studies found similar fish abundances between no-fishing Marine Protected Areas and fished areas.

One study reported long-term declines of some sharks in areas where enforcement of fishing prohibitions was poor.

No-fishing or no-entry zones had greater fish biomass or abundance than fished zones and outside areas after 3 to 27 years.

question_details.query: Besides changing hook type in longline fisheries, what other gear modifications can reduce unwanted catches of sharks and rays?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence indicates that modifying longline configuration can reduce unwanted shark and ray catches: increasing lead weight on mid-water longlines to increase sinking rate reduced catches of unwanted sharks and/or rays, and using nylon instead of wire hook attachments reduced unwanted shark/ray catches in some cases (2699). Deploying fishing gear at selected depths, including above the seabed instead of on it, reduced unwanted catches of three of eight shark/ray species in replicated studies (2683).
summary_statements: Evidence indicates that modifying longline configuration can reduce unwanted shark and ray catches.
Increasing lead weight on mid-water longlines to increase the sinking rate reduced catches of unwanted sharks and rays.
Using nylon instead of wire hook attachments reduced unwanted shark and ray catches in some cases.
Deploying fishing gear at selected depths reduced unwanted catches of some shark and ray species in replicated studies.
Deploying fishing gear above the seabed instead of on the seabed reduced unwanted catches of some shark and ray species.

question_details.query: What gear modifications are available to reduce the unwanted catch of cod and haddock in the North Sea?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence from North Sea studies indicates several trawl-gear modifications are available to reduce unwanted catches of cod and haddock. A separator trawl separated unwanted cod into a lower codend where a larger mesh allowed more smaller cod to escape (2711). Topless (coverless) trawls reduced unwanted Atlantic cod, and reduced unwanted larger haddock but not smaller haddock, while larger cod reductions occurred only in one of two cases (2712). Size‑sorting escape grids fitted to trawl nets reduced unwanted sizes of cod and other non‑target fish including haddock in multiple regions that include the North Sea, and in North Sea/Norwegian Sea studies grids improved size‑selection for haddock though not consistently for cod, with one study finding no improvement versus square‑mesh windows (2720). Fitting mesh escape panels/windows (square or large diamond) to trawl nets reduced unwanted catches including cod and haddock in several North Sea studies, and reviews/experiments reported improved size‑selectivity for Atlantic cod and haddock, with effects varying by panel design and position (2716). Modifying the position and/or size of mesh escape panels improved size‑selectivity for haddock in North Sea studies, though some studies reported no reduction in unwanted cod (2717).
summary_statements: Evidence from North Sea studies indicates several trawl-gear modifications are available to reduce unwanted catches of cod and haddock.
A separator trawl separated unwanted cod into a lower codend.
The lower codend of the separator trawl had a larger mesh that allowed more smaller cod to escape.

question_details.query: How do mesh escape panels, size-sorting grids, and large supported openings compare in their effectiveness at improving size-selectivity in trawl nets?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across trawl fisheries, size-sorting escape grids frequently reduced unwanted fish catches and sometimes improved size-selectivity: in fish trawls, grids reduced undersized or non-target catches in most studies and improved size-selection for haddock in some cases but not for saithe or cod, and did not outperform square-mesh escape windows in one comparison [2720]; in prawn/shrimp trawls, grids often reduced unwanted fish (including sharks) across multiple regions, though effects varied by species, site, year, and grid type, with several studies finding no reduction or mixed outcomes [2721]. Large, supported escape openings (e.g., Fisheyes, Bigeyes, radial sections) generally reduced unwanted fish and total unwanted catch in most trials, with species-specific results (e.g., fewer unwanted Chinook salmon in both opening designs tested, mixed effects for widow rockfish), and one study reported reduced unwanted sharks but not rays or sawfish compared to standard nets [2723]. Mesh escape panels/windows showed mixed effects: modifying panel position/size sometimes improved size-selectivity for haddock and whiting while effects for cod were similar to standard trawls, and reductions in unwanted catches were inconsistent across species and studies [2717]. Combining devices tended to enhance selectivity and bycatch reduction: panels/windows plus grids reduced unwanted fish, rays, sharks, and total discards in several studies and increased size-selectivity of whiting, with escape occurring via either device depending on species/size [2727]; grids combined with large supported openings reduced unwanted fish and sharks/rays in most studies, with exceptions (no reduction in sharks in one study; no reduction in sawfish) [2726].

question_details.query: What are the comparative effects on fish abundance of prohibiting all static fishing gear versus prohibiting only line fishing?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Prohibiting all non-towed (static) fishing gear: One replicated, site-comparison study in the Coral Sea found that areas closed to non-towed fishing gears had higher overall shark abundance when sampled with longlines, but not when sampled with gillnets, compared to areas where commercial gillnets were permitted [2670]. Prohibiting line fishing: One site-comparison study in the Indian Ocean (South Africa) reported that closing a zone to offshore line fishing and all other boat-based fishing resulted in higher abundances of four of four fish species over-exploited by line fishing, compared to two zones where boat-based line and spear fishing were permitted [2671].
summary_statements: A study in the Coral Sea found that areas closed to non-towed fishing gears had higher overall shark abundance when sampled with longlines compared to areas where commercial gillnets were permitted.

The same study in the Coral Sea found that areas closed to non-towed fishing gears did not have higher overall shark abundance when sampled with gillnets compared to areas where commercial gillnets were permitted.

question_details.query: What are the outcomes for fish populations when marine protected areas are managed with zonation systems that permit some fishing?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across eight studies of marine protected areas managed with zonation, fish outcomes generally varied with the level of fishing restriction: fish species richness was higher in no‑fishing/no‑access zones than in partially fished zones and unprotected areas 10–15 years after implementation; average lengths of several species were larger within no‑take zones than in partially fished zones three years after implementation; densities, biomass, and abundance were typically higher in non‑fished zones (no‑entry or no‑take) than in fished zones within the same protected areas, although effects varied among fish groups, sizes, protection levels, and regions; in one case, a zone closed to fishing but open to other recreation had a different age and sex structure than a multipurpose fished zone, and both differed from an unprotected low‑exploitation site; and tagged reef fishes were mostly recaptured near release sites and mainly within zones where all or nearly all fishing was prohibited for up to 20 years. [2674]
summary_statements: Fish species richness was higher in no‑fishing/no‑access zones than in partially fished zones and unprotected areas 10 to 15 years after implementation.

question_details.query: How does the effectiveness of prohibiting mobile bottom fishing gear vary between the North Atlantic and other regions like the Mediterranean or Indian Ocean?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across regions, reported outcomes vary. In the Mediterranean, areas closed to all bottom‑towed gears for 14 years showed higher biomass and larger sizes of adult red mullet and increased recruitment of young red mullet compared to before closure or to fished areas [2673]. In the North Atlantic, an area closed to bottom trawling did not show higher recruitment or survival of young haddock seven years after closure compared to a trawled area [2673], whereas other closures that prohibited mobile and static bottom gears for 5–15 years reported cod with better growth and higher numbers of larger and older individuals than in openly fished areas [2654]. For benthic invertebrates, North Sea sites (part of the North Atlantic) closed to trawling for 15 years had different community composition and higher diversity than trawled sites [2099], while Mediterranean sites closed for 20 years had different composition but showed no differences in overall invertebrate diversity or abundance compared to trawled sites in one study [2099]. Evidence from studies conducted across multiple regions, including the Indian Ocean, indicates that effects on fish size in areas prohibiting bottom‑towed gears varied between fish groups and with habitat type, and in some cases closures had no effect on average fish weight or on combined fish and invertebrate sizes [2673].

question_details.query: How do separator trawls and topless trawls compare in their effectiveness at reducing unwanted fish catch?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across action documents, topless (coverless) trawls and separator trawls both show evidence of reducing unwanted fish, with differences in consistency and context. For topless trawls, four replicated, controlled studies reported mixed but often positive effects: reduced catches of unwanted Atlantic cod and discards of commercial species in some trials, size‐dependent reductions for haddock (larger fish reduced, smaller not), and reductions for only one of four commercial species in another case (2712). For separator trawls, two studies reported targeted reductions via gear design: one randomized North Sea study showed unwanted cod were directed into a lower codend with larger mesh that allowed more smaller cod to escape, and another Atlantic study found that adding a square‑mesh escape panel reduced catches of one of two unwanted fish species in a crustacean fishery (2711). Overall, topless trawls show mixed reductions across species and sizes, while separator trawls demonstrate design‑mediated separation that reduced some unwanted species or sizes in specific configurations (2712, 2711).

question_details.query: What are the documented effects of modifying fishing trap or pot configurations on marine fish?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across 23 studies in multiple regions, modifying trap/pot configurations was evaluated for effects on marine fish [2702]. One replicated, controlled study found survival of small herring that escaped through a size‑sorting grid was similar to survival of trap‑caught herring that did not pass through a grid [2702]. Sixteen of 20 replicated studies (plus one before‑and‑after) reported that configuration changes (e.g., different trap types, larger mesh, escape devices) reduced unwanted catches of fish overall or specific species (including brown trout, black sea bass, herring, bluethroat wrasse and leatherjacket, cod, protected rockfishes, whitefish, American eel, winter flounder, sharks/rays), with three studies finding no reduction for some species (e.g., white croaker, non‑commercial fish, undersized Atlantic cod) and one reporting increased non‑target haddock; one study also noted creels did not catch high proportions of immature fish compared to bottom trawls [2702]. Size‑selectivity improved in three of four replicated studies when traps/pots had square‑mesh escape windows or larger mesh, benefiting Atlantic cod, black sea bass, and most fish species; one study found no effect for panga [2702]. Modifications designed to exclude mammals on trap‑ or bag‑nets reduced seal damage to salmon catches and led to higher catches of undamaged salmon but not whitefish [2822].

question_details.query: What is the evidence for using electropositive deterrents on fishing gear to reduce unwanted catches of sharks and rays?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Nine studies tested electropositive deterrents on fishing gear, spanning the Atlantic Ocean (USA, Canada, Bahamas), Gulf of Alaska, South Pacific Ocean and Tasman Sea, plus two laboratory studies and one global systematic review (2696). Behavioural evidence from three of four replicated studies (including paired/controlled and randomized designs) showed reduced feeding attempts or bait consumption by spiny dogfish, great hammerhead and draughtboard sharks when deterrent materials were attached near bait; one study found no reduction for bonnethead and young lemon sharks, and one study reported no effect on bait consumption by commercially valuable Pacific halibut (2696). Catch outcomes from two of four replicated, controlled field studies (one randomized) reported fewer unwanted catches of spiny dogfish, longnose skate, and combined sharks and rays on longlines and traps, and fewer undersized halibut, when electropositive deterrents were used versus standard or non-deterrent gear; the other two field studies and a global systematic review found no reduction, with catches of spiny dogfish, total sharks, blue shark, and combined sharks and rays similar to controls (2696).

question_details.query: In European waters, what does the evidence show about the effectiveness of using a square mesh codend instead of a diamond mesh codend for reducing unwanted catch?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across replicated, controlled studies that include European seas (English Channel, Bristol Channel, Aegean, Adriatic, Mediterranean, Kattegat/Skagerrak), 10 of 16 studies reported that square mesh codends reduced unwanted catch (non-target/discarded fish and invertebrates), while four studies found no reduction; one study found square mesh codends retained more fish overall, and one found unwanted catch depended on both mesh size and configuration; in studies with no or varied effects, increasing mesh size improved selectivity for both codend types (2714). In the English Channel, one replicated, paired, controlled study found a square mesh codend caught fewer non-commercial invertebrates in one of two areas and similar amounts in the other (2136). In the English Channel, adding square-mesh escape panels with a square mesh codend reduced numbers of discarded finfish (2724) and reduced non-commercial invertebrate bycatch (2138).

question_details.query: What are the documented benefits of ceasing all fishing in a marine protected area on fish community composition and species richness?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Seven site comparison studies found that marine protected areas where all fishing had been prohibited for 3–16 years had a different fish community composition compared to fished areas [2682]. Regarding species richness/diversity, 14 of 20 site comparison studies found higher fish species richness in non‑fished marine protected areas 1 to >25 years after implementation compared to fished areas; six studies found similar richness, one systematic review in the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans found no difference, and one replicated study in the Indian Ocean reported that effects after 15 years varied with the sampling method used [2682]. In marine protected areas closed to all fishing with limited exceptions in the Caribbean Sea for up to seven years, one site comparison study found lower total fish species richness compared to unprotected areas [2681].
summary_statements: Seven site comparison studies found that marine protected areas where all fishing had been prohibited for 3–16 years had a different fish community composition compared to fished areas.

question_details.query: How does using a square mesh codend compare to rotating a diamond mesh codend for improving size-selectivity in trawl nets?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across 14 replicated, controlled studies, using a square mesh codend improved size selectivity in six studies (for species such as silver hake, horse mackerel, European hake, axillary seabream, poor cod, greater forkbeard, blue whiting, discarded fish, and three of four commercially targeted fish), showed no difference in five studies (e.g., Atlantic mackerel, long rough dab, yellowtail scad and striped seapike, rockfish and flatfish, and three of four commercially important bottom fish species), and varied with body shape in three studies (improved for roundfish but not for at least one flatfish); some studies also reported that increasing mesh size raised size selectivity for both square and diamond meshes [2714]. Turning diamond mesh by 90° improved size selection for cod, red mullet, common pandora, and round-bodied fish in a review and four of five replicated, controlled studies, but not for plaice, annular sea bream, and flatfish; one study found no improvement for cod, plaice, and flounder [2715].
summary_statements: In six of fourteen replicated, controlled studies, using a square mesh codend improved size selectivity.

In the South Atlantic Ocean, a site comparison study found no change in species composition between a reserve closed to all commercial fishing for 40 years and unprotected fished areas (2667).

question_details.query: What does the evidence suggest about the timeframe over which prohibiting all fishing in a marine protected area leads to increased fish abundance?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across 54 site comparison studies, 30 found higher fish abundances (density and/or biomass) inside marine protected areas where all fishing was prohibited for up to 25 years or more, compared to fished areas [2682]. Five of six reviews reported higher fish abundances in non‑fished marine reserves with 1–27 years of protection, compared to fished areas [2682]. Eight studies reported similar abundances between protected and fished areas 1–20 years after prohibiting fishing, and 16 studies reported effects that varied among species or groups after 3–20 years of protection [2682].

question_details.query: What is the evidence from global reviews on the effectiveness of catch share systems for managing fish stocks sustainably?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Two worldwide systematic reviews examined fisheries under catch share systems [3812]. One review found that fisheries or stocks managed under catch shares were more likely to meet management target levels for biomass sustainability [3812], while another found no difference in the performance of biomass-based management targets between fisheries under catch shares, fleet-wide catch caps, or fishing effort controls [3812]. Both reviews reported that catch share fisheries had lower rates of over-exploitation than non-catch share fisheries, and a higher proportion met or exceeded management target levels for rates of exploitation [3812]. A global systematic review also reported that, in terms of reaching biomass-based management targets, fisheries with fleet-wide catch quotas were no different to those managed by catch shares or effort controls; however, along with catch share fisheries, fewer catch quota stocks were over-exploited than those with effort controls [3811].
summary_statements: Two worldwide systematic reviews examined fisheries under catch share systems.
One review found that fisheries or stocks managed under catch shares were more likely to meet management target levels for biomass sustainability.

question_details.query: What are the comparative effects of long-term versus temporary fishery closures on marine fish populations?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Temporary closures: Across five studies, a before-and-after, site comparison in the Atlantic found no increase in spawning stock biomass, survival, or length composition of cod over nine years following a temporary closure compared to fished areas (2664). A Northeast Atlantic tagging study reported adult cod spent nearly a third of their time inside a seasonally closed spawning area during implementation (2664). In the North Sea, fixed temporary closures had little effect on cod fishing effort, whereas real-time area closures reduced the annual amount of cod caught (retained and discarded) (2664). In targeted fisheries, catch rates of red mullet and total catch (fish and invertebrates combined) increased after temporary closures over 10 years, but not European hake (2664); another Atlantic before-and-after, site comparison found no change in cod catches over nine years (2664). During a grouper closure, spear-fisher catches of herbivores increased, indicating a shift in targeting (2664). Long-term closures: Across five studies, replicated before-and-after work in the Norwegian Sea found higher weights of young salmon (but similar or lower weights of older salmon) after long-term closure of a commercial coastal fishery, and more young salmon (but similar older salmon) returning to rivers compared to before (2655). Site comparisons found mixed abundance responses: higher abundance for only one of seven species and lower monkfish abundance inside year-round groundfish closures of six–eight years (2655). In the North Sea, lesser sandeel biomass and density peaked but did not show an overall increase three years after long-term closure, and annual sandeel catches varied after an indefinite closure (2655). Inside an area closed to customary fishing for eight years, six of seven species had reduced flight response distance (2655). Additional outcomes included reduced unwanted cod catch where long-term closures were combined with gear-limited areas, and reduced overall fishing effort for lesser sandeel (2655).
summary_statements: A before-and-after, site comparison in the Atlantic found no increase in spawning stock biomass, survival, or length composition of cod over nine years following a temporary closure compared to fished areas.

question_details.query: What are the observed effects of fitting deterrents, such as lights or electropositive materials, to fishing gear?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across studies, electropositive deterrents attached to gear sometimes reduced unwanted catches of sharks, rays, spiny dogfish, and undersized halibut, though several studies and a systematic review reported similar unwanted catch to gear without deterrents; behaviourally, some shark species showed reduced feeding attempts and bait consumption near deterrents, while others did not, and halibut feeding was unaffected [2696]. Adding artificial lights to gear reduced unwanted fish in shrimp trawls when lights were fitted to the fishing line (but not when attached to a size-sorting grid), and lights did not improve size-selectivity for several fish species on a grid [2695]. For reptiles, lights on gillnets reduced green and loggerhead turtle bycatch in multiple studies, with one study reporting no loggerhead mortalities in UV-lit nets compared to some in unlit nets, while increasing longline light sticks had mixed effects on loggerhead and leatherback catch rates [3554]. Visual deterrents (e.g., floating shark shapes) on gillnets reduced green turtle catch in one study, though captive tests showed mixed behavioural responses to shark-shaped and spherical deterrents [3553].
summary_statements: Electropositive deterrents attached to fishing gear sometimes reduced unwanted catches of sharks, rays, spiny dogfish, and undersized halibut.
Several studies and a systematic review reported that unwanted catch rates were similar for gear with and without electropositive deterrents.

question_details.query: What are the most effective spatial management actions for protecting spawning fish and their habitats?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence from 79 studies indicates that prohibiting all fishing in marine protected areas (no‑take MPAs) is associated in many cases with higher fish abundance/biomass, higher species richness, larger fish sizes, increased egg production for targeted species, greater use of protected areas by sharks and commercially important reef fishes, reduced fishing mortality for tagged fishes, higher stock biomass, and in some cases elevated catch rates near reserve boundaries, although effects can vary by species, habitat, and enforcement [2682]. Protecting spawning fish from capture via seasonal or permanent closures shows mixed population outcomes: a North Atlantic before‑after comparison found no increase in cod spawning stock biomass, survival, or size and no change in commercial catches over nine years, while tracking showed substantial use of closed spawning/nursery areas by cod and juvenile sharks, and a seasonal grouper closure shifted spear‑fishing effort toward herbivores [2938]. Establishing temporary fishery closures similarly showed no cod biomass, survival, or size increase over nine years in one Atlantic study, but tagged cod spent about one‑third of time inside a seasonal spawning closure during implementation, real‑time area closures reduced annual cod caught, some targeted fisheries showed increased catch rates after closures, and spear‑fishers targeted herbivores more during a grouper closure [2664]. Areas allowing only periodic fishing had greater fish biomass than openly fished areas and similar biomass to permanently closed areas, with higher catch rates than open areas over 18 months to six years [2679].

question_details.query: How does the effectiveness of no-take marine protected areas on fish communities differ between the Mediterranean Sea and the Indian Ocean?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across studies of no‑take marine protected areas, 15 studies were in the Indian Ocean and 12 in the Mediterranean Sea [2682]. In both regions, site comparisons reported different fish community composition in no‑take areas versus fished areas after 3–16 years [2682]. For richness/diversity, studies including both regions often found higher species richness in no‑take areas, but one replicated Indian Ocean study found the effect on species richness/diversity after 15 years varied with sampling method [2682]. For abundance, multiple studies across regions (including the Mediterranean and Indian Oceans) reported higher fish abundance or biomass in no‑take areas, while other studies found similar or mixed effects depending on species, trophic position, size, habitat, or protection duration [2682]. Region‑specific findings included: Mediterranean—more eggs of four commercially targeted fish species inside a no‑take reserve enforced for three years, and higher small‑scale commercial catch rates closest to a 22‑year no‑take reserve, decreasing with distance [2682]; Indian Ocean—higher fish grazing rates in no‑take areas protected for 1 and 24 years, highest reef‑fish stock biomass in enforced no‑take areas compared to other management regimes, and most individuals of five fish species remaining within a no‑take reserve over nine years [2682].
